item.title: Google Meet's new feature does your makeup for you before that next big meeting
item.itunes:title: Google Meet's new feature does your makeup for you before that next big meeting
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
Summary

  • Google Meet adds AI-powered makeup with 12 studio looks for an effortless, natural look.
  • Makeup stays seamless during movements like sipping or touching your face.
  • Rolling out Oct 8 on web/desktop; rollout completes in ~15 days and it saves your look.

I don't know about you, but before I enter a Google Meet meeting, I always make sure I'm looking as presentable as possible. Sure, in our big XDA calls, nobody's going to call me out if I'm looking particularly rough, but it's a personal pride thing, you know? I just want to make sure I'm looking my best when it's time to discuss my work for the week.

For some people, a Google Meet call is a good excuse to crack open the make-up case and make themselves look truly stunning. However, for those of us who'd rather not go through the effort, Google has a solution. The company has announced that you can use an AI-powered makeup tool to look your best, and it'll work no matter what you throw at it.

Google Meet harnesses the power of AI to make you look fabulous

Image Credit: Google

On the Google Workspace Update blog, the company describes its plans for the new Google Meet feature. It's an addition to the touch-up feature, and it helps you do your makeup so you don't have to:

Last year, we introduced Touch-up in Google Meet on the web to give users more control over their appearance in video calls. We’ve been working to help everyone better express their personal style on every call, and we’re excited to expand the feature with AI-powered makeup.

Now you can choose from 12 new studio makeup looks, with a range of options from a polished, professional touch to a more expressive flair. Your AI-powered makeup remains seamless and untouched—even through everyday movements like sipping your coffee or touching your face.

You can see Google Product Manager Daniela use the feature in the GIF above. Note how she can turn on the makeup feature and sip from her mug without the colors breaking. It really looks like she applied the makeup herself when, in fact, all she had to do was hit a button. Truly, the sheer might of AI tools has arrived.

If you want to give this feature a try for yourself, Google says that it's currently rolling out the feature across its users. According to the blog post, it began the rollout on October 8th, and it will take 15 days for it to arrive for everyone. Once you've set it up, you can use the makeup feature on either the web or desktop client, and it'll remember your selection for your next meeting. And if the idea of hosting a call brings you dread, check out these apps that make scheduling meetings way less painful.

item.title: This "overwhelmingly positive" rated game, where your choices truly matter, is just $8 on Steam right now
item.itunes:title: This "overwhelmingly positive" rated game, where your choices truly matter, is just $8 on Steam right now
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
There are only a few games out there that claim to have a "choices matter" story where the choices really, truly matter. There are some games where it feels like, no matter what you pick, you're basically led into the exact same plot with some minor changes.

However, Detroit: Become Human is all about the choices you make. In fact, the game actively wants you to explore all of the outcomes you can experience, based on the decisions you pick. And if that sounds like something you want to try, the game has just fallen to its lowest price ever on Steam with a respectable 80% off its asking price.

Detroit: Become Human falls to just $8 on Steam

Detroit: Become Human is a unique title that presents a question: if androids become truly human-like, then how should we as a society handle them? Should we regard them as robots and tools for our bidding, or should we instead give them the same rights as humans?

The game gives you some crucial decisions to make during the story, and they change how the story unfolds. In fact, the game has a timeline feature where you can see where the plot branched off and tells you how to see the other nodes to experience the story in full.

Here's how the devs describe the game:

Detroit 2038. Technology has evolved to a point where human like androids are everywhere. They speak, move and behave like human beings, but they are only machines serving humans.

Play three distinct androids and see a world at the brink of chaos – perhaps our future - through their eyes. Your very decisions will dramatically alter how the game’s intense, branching narrative plays out.

You will face moral dilemmas and decide who lives or dies. With thousands of choices and dozens of possible endings, how will you affect the future of Detroit and humanity’s destiny?

If you want to give it a try for yourself, it's currently on sale over on Steam for just $8. That's the lowest we've ever seen go on sale on Valve's platform; last time it went on sale, it was at 70% off. As such, if you've been thinking of picking this one up, be sure to grab it before the deal expires on October 20th.

item.title: I still don't understand why these 8 PowerToys features aren't built into Windows
item.itunes:title: I still don't understand why these 8 PowerToys features aren't built into Windows
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
I've talked to no end about how PowerToys is an essential tool if you use a Windows PC. It adds so much to your arsenal of tools and improves Windows 11 in some major ways, to the point where I believe some of these tools should just be built into Windows 11 at this point. For some of those tools, I wish they were built-in because I love them, but others just make sense, even if they're not personally my thing.

I find it strange that Windows itself has become so boring with its updates when Microsoft has the potential to do so much with Windows 11, and the tools are right there already. Especially when the competition seems much less afraid to innovate and make things more interesting.

FancyZones

This shouldn't be a hard decision

I've mentioned before that I strongly feel FancyZones should be a part of Windows 11, and over time, that opinion has only been reinforced. It's become especially clear to me now that I realized some Linux desktops already have this feature built in and implemented to near perfection. Specifically, KDE Plasma has a window manager that works almost exactly like FancyZones, albeit somewhat simplified, and it's fantastic.

It just makes me wonder why Microsoft won't build this into Windows 11, too. When you have a very large monitor, FancyZones makes it incredibly easy to create custom layouts for your windows to snap into, allowing you to finetune your workspace to your specific needs. Not only that, but it makes it very easy to actually snap those apps into the respective areas, since you only need to hold an activation key and enter the area from any point. This is something KDE Plasma also does perfectly without the need for extra add-ons, and after so long, I don't get why Microsoft wouldn't do the same.

Hosts file editor

Why does this still feel like a hack?

The hosts file is something that's been in Windows for a very long time, and it allows you to add addresses you want to forbid your computer from connecting to. This can be used as a way to block traffic to specific sites, but it can also help block ads, or bypass the DNS resolver on your network, for example.

You've always been able to edit the hosts file in Notepad, but importantly, you would first need to know it exists and where it is, and it's understandable why some users might not want to be messing with a relatively hidden file, as it might suggest it's not something you should touch. But the Hosts File Editor in PowerToys makes this file very easy to edit with a nice UI, and frankly, this feels like a feature that should be in the Control Panel or the Settings app, even if it's still buried in advanced options. The option to configure hostnames and IP addresses should be easier to access.

Peek

If macOS is doing it...

Windows does many things better than macOS, but Apple's operating system also has its own benefits. And a big one is the ability to quickly preview files by pressing the space bar after selecting them in Finder. Even better, the focus remains on Finder, so you can use the arrow keys to navigate a folder and keep previewing all the files.

That description alone should make it obvious why this is a great feature to have built right into the operating system, and Microsoft sees the value in it, too, considering we have Peek in PowerToys to achieve a similar result. While it's not as polished as the macOS implementation, it's still very useful, and it drives home the point that this really needs to be part of Windows itself. It needs to happen, and sooner rather than later.

File Explorer add-ons

A natural addition

I've talked about File Explorer add-ons before and how they make the experience using the Windows file manager noticeably better, but out of all the items on this list, this is probably the most baffling. It's not easy to understand why something so basic and intrinsic to the File Explorer experience requires an add-on.

It's not even that I particularly need the features the add-on provides, but if it's possible to implement previews of more file types in File Explorer, what exactly is Microsoft waiting for? Why do you need an additional app to preview what a 3D print file looks like? Simply put, it makes no sense, and it needs to be part of Windows.

Quick Accent

It's so helpful

I've brought up macOS a couple of times already, but I need to do it again because of yet another feature Microsoft seemingly refuses to put in Windows 11. Quick Accent is a feature in PowerToys that lets you hold a character press an activation key to see every variation of that character with different accents. As you might have guessed, macOS does this too by simply holding down the key for the character you want to add the accent to, which makes it even more odd that Microsoft won't adopt it as well.

This can be useful for various reasons. For one thing, if you need to type a foreign name such as my own, it gives you access to accents without having to set up and learn the United States International keyboard. But it can also be useful for small keyboard layouts that may be missing certain accent keys. It really just makes the computer more usable for more types of users.

PowerRename

A decent renaming tool is long overdue

Did you know that it's possible to rename files in bulk on Windows? It isn't easy to tell, but you can in fact select multiple files and rename them in one go — Windows just shows no indication that this is actually working until you've entered the name you want. Plus there aren't many options for tweaking how renaming works.

PowerRename is a tool that fixes this. It's a much more robust renaming tool that allows you to add suffixes and prefixes to a name based on specific rules, and it easily lets you preview the final name for each file you've selected. Many other platforms, including macOS and certain Linux file managers, also make it easy to rename files in bulk with different options available, but for some reason, Windows can only offer a good experience with PowerToys.

Not that PowerRename is perfect by any means, but adding it to Windows itself would at least bring it more in line with the competition, and it's high time for that to happen.

Always on Top

Simple, but useful

I'm sure everyone has been in a situation where they wished they could pin a window on top of all others while multitasking, and many apps even have that capability in some capacity. For example, a lot of media players have a picture-in-picture mode, including most modern web browsers.

But being able to pin any app window on top of other windows is something you can only do with PowerToys, thanks to the Always on Top tool. Of course, that's not necessarily the case with other operating systems. On Linux, a desktop environment like COSMIC can offer this exact feature, but it's seemingly too much to ask of Windows. I'll admit this isn't something I personally need very often, but if a newcomer like COSMIC can do it and Microsoft knows there's a use for it, why not just build it into Windows?

File Locksmith

An important troubleshooting tool

Have you ever tried to delete a file only for Windows to tell you that you can't because it's being used by another process? It's not a very common occurence, but it's not exactly unheard of, either, and of all things, it's weird that such an important fix wouldn't be included in Windows when Microsoft already has the tool available.

File Locksmith is a simple PowerToys utility that lets you right-click a file and check any processes that may be using it, along with providing the option to terminate said processes if you want to close the file. It's simple, but if you're constantly running into issues deleting a file you really want gone from your PC, this is incredibly useful, and when it's solving such a big pain point, it's hard to understand why it isn't just part of Windows. Again, this is a tool I wouldn't use that frequently, but it's clearly something that should just be there by default.

Microsoft is actively holding Windows back

It's frustrating to see all these tools in PowerToys missing out on proper Windows integration when it's clear that not only does Microsoft see value in these features, but its competitors have taken the initiative and built similar features into their own platforms, leaving Windows in the dust. It's one of many reasons I find myself happier on other platforms these days, and I suspect many others may feel the same way. It's time for Microsoft to step up and improve Windows already.

I find it strange that Windows itself has become so boring with its updates when Microsoft has the potential to do so much with Windows 11, and the tools are right there already. Especially when the competition seems much less afraid to innovate and make things more interesting.

FancyZones

This shouldn't be a hard decision

I've mentioned before that I strongly feel FancyZones should be a part of Windows 11, and over time, that opinion has only been reinforced. It's become especially clear to me now that I realized some Linux desktops already have this feature built in and implemented to near perfection. Specifically, KDE Plasma has a window manager that works almost exactly like FancyZones, albeit somewhat simplified, and it's fantastic.

It just makes me wonder why Microsoft won't build this into Windows 11, too. When you have a very large monitor, FancyZones makes it incredibly easy to create custom layouts for your windows to snap into, allowing you to finetune your workspace to your specific needs. Not only that, but it makes it very easy to actually snap those apps into the respective areas, since you only need to hold an activation key and enter the area from any point. This is something KDE Plasma also does perfectly without the need for extra add-ons, and after so long, I don't get why Microsoft wouldn't do the same.

Hosts file editor

Why does this still feel like a hack?

The hosts file is something that's been in Windows for a very long time, and it allows you to add addresses you want to forbid your computer from connecting to. This can be used as a way to block traffic to specific sites, but it can also help block ads, or bypass the DNS resolver on your network, for example.

You've always been able to edit the hosts file in Notepad, but importantly, you would first need to know it exists and where it is, and it's understandable why some users might not want to be messing with a relatively hidden file, as it might suggest it's not something you should touch. But the Hosts File Editor in PowerToys makes this file very easy to edit with a nice UI, and frankly, this feels like a feature that should be in the Control Panel or the Settings app, even if it's still buried in advanced options. The option to configure hostnames and IP addresses should be easier to access.

Peek

If macOS is doing it...

Windows does many things better than macOS, but Apple's operating system also has its own benefits. And a big one is the ability to quickly preview files by pressing the space bar after selecting them in Finder. Even better, the focus remains on Finder, so you can use the arrow keys to navigate a folder and keep previewing all the files.

That description alone should make it obvious why this is a great feature to have built right into the operating system, and Microsoft sees the value in it, too, considering we have Peek in PowerToys to achieve a similar result. While it's not as polished as the macOS implementation, it's still very useful, and it drives home the point that this really needs to be part of Windows itself. It needs to happen, and sooner rather than later.

File Explorer add-ons

A natural addition

I've talked about File Explorer add-ons before and how they make the experience using the Windows file manager noticeably better, but out of all the items on this list, this is probably the most baffling. It's not easy to understand why something so basic and intrinsic to the File Explorer experience requires an add-on.

It's not even that I particularly need the features the add-on provides, but if it's possible to implement previews of more file types in File Explorer, what exactly is Microsoft waiting for? Why do you need an additional app to preview what a 3D print file looks like? Simply put, it makes no sense, and it needs to be part of Windows.

Quick Accent

It's so helpful

I've brought up macOS a couple of times already, but I need to do it again because of yet another feature Microsoft seemingly refuses to put in Windows 11. Quick Accent is a feature in PowerToys that lets you hold a character press an activation key to see every variation of that character with different accents. As you might have guessed, macOS does this too by simply holding down the key for the character you want to add the accent to, which makes it even more odd that Microsoft won't adopt it as well.

This can be useful for various reasons. For one thing, if you need to type a foreign name such as my own, it gives you access to accents without having to set up and learn the United States International keyboard. But it can also be useful for small keyboard layouts that may be missing certain accent keys. It really just makes the computer more usable for more types of users.

PowerRename

A decent renaming tool is long overdue

Did you know that it's possible to rename files in bulk on Windows? It isn't easy to tell, but you can in fact select multiple files and rename them in one go — Windows just shows no indication that this is actually working until you've entered the name you want. Plus there aren't many options for tweaking how renaming works.

PowerRename is a tool that fixes this. It's a much more robust renaming tool that allows you to add suffixes and prefixes to a name based on specific rules, and it easily lets you preview the final name for each file you've selected. Many other platforms, including macOS and certain Linux file managers, also make it easy to rename files in bulk with different options available, but for some reason, Windows can only offer a good experience with PowerToys.

Not that PowerRename is perfect by any means, but adding it to Windows itself would at least bring it more in line with the competition, and it's high time for that to happen.

Always on Top

Simple, but useful

I'm sure everyone has been in a situation where they wished they could pin a window on top of all others while multitasking, and many apps even have that capability in some capacity. For example, a lot of media players have a picture-in-picture mode, including most modern web browsers.

But being able to pin any app window on top of other windows is something you can only do with PowerToys, thanks to the Always on Top tool. Of course, that's not necessarily the case with other operating systems. On Linux, a desktop environment like COSMIC can offer this exact feature, but it's seemingly too much to ask of Windows. I'll admit this isn't something I personally need very often, but if a newcomer like COSMIC can do it and Microsoft knows there's a use for it, why not just build it into Windows?

File Locksmith

An important troubleshooting tool

Have you ever tried to delete a file only for Windows to tell you that you can't because it's being used by another process? It's not a very common occurence, but it's not exactly unheard of, either, and of all things, it's weird that such an important fix wouldn't be included in Windows when Microsoft already has the tool available.

File Locksmith is a simple PowerToys utility that lets you right-click a file and check any processes that may be using it, along with providing the option to terminate said processes if you want to close the file. It's simple, but if you're constantly running into issues deleting a file you really want gone from your PC, this is incredibly useful, and when it's solving such a big pain point, it's hard to understand why it isn't just part of Windows. Again, this is a tool I wouldn't use that frequently, but it's clearly something that should just be there by default.

Microsoft is actively holding Windows back

It's frustrating to see all these tools in PowerToys missing out on proper Windows integration when it's clear that not only does Microsoft see value in these features, but its competitors have taken the initiative and built similar features into their own platforms, leaving Windows in the dust. It's one of many reasons I find myself happier on other platforms these days, and I suspect many others may feel the same way. It's time for Microsoft to step up and improve Windows already.

item.title: 6 PC components that I absolutely love but won't recommend to most gamers
item.itunes:title: 6 PC components that I absolutely love but won't recommend to most gamers
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
When it comes to PC hardware, my wishlist is overflowing with components I'd love to have in my PC setup. From visually stunning cases and RAM kits and overkill coolers and SSDs to the fastest CPUs and GPUs, there's probably no gamer who'd refuse a chance to own these fantastic PC parts. That said, I'd advise most gamers against buying these particular models. Despite how great they are, they aren't the best choice when it comes to maximizing FPS per dollar — you have numerous better options on the market.

HYTE Y70 Touch Infinite

A touch overkill for almost everyone

HYTE is no stranger to producing jaw-dropping PC cases, many of which have exploded in popularity in recent years. For instance, the HYTE Y40 is a gorgeous all-white case that excels in features as well as airflow. The one I'm in love with, however, is the HYTE Y70 Touch Infinite, a dual-chamber mid-tower case with a massive 15-inch touchscreen. Just like any other dual-chamber case, it can fit almost any build, and the pre-installed riser is perfect for vertical GPU enthusiasts.

The pièce de résistance, however, is the crisp 15-inch touch display that isn't just there for eye candy. Yes, you can display your typical GIFs on it, but the touchscreen allows you to control a bunch of stuff happening on your PC. The Y70 Touch Infinite looks unlike any other case, but the asking price is a bit too steep for the majority of PC builders. At $400 (or $350 during sales), it's a premium product that I can't recommend to the average gamer. Most people in need of a dual-chamber mid-tower case shouldn't spend over $150 — this HYTE offering costs over three times as much. It's overkill even for an overkill PC.

Noctua NH-D15

The famed air cooler isn't for the average gamer

The Noctua NH-D15 needs no introduction — it's remained one of the best air coolers ever since its debut over a decade ago. It can easily go head-to-head with many 360mm AIO liquid coolers, and continues to be popular with PC builders even in 2025. However, I would advise most gamers against it, unless you have a generous budget for an air cooler. At around $130, it's by no means an "affordable" air cooler, and is expensive even for its excellent performance.

For starters, there are far cheaper alternatives that perform just as well for most builds. Thermalright's Peerless Assassin 120 for around $35 is an easy recommendation. Unless you're running a Ryzen 9, Core i9, or Core Ultra 9 processor or have plans for CPU overclocking, you'll be just fine with a budget air cooler. Secondly, the beige-and-brown Noctua esthetic doesn't work for everyone. Lastly, the NH-D15 is just too big for many cases, dominating the visual footprint of your build, often negatively. Many compact cases won't be able to accommodate it in the first place. A cheap air cooler or $100 AIO liquid cooler are overall better choices than the phenomenal NH-D15.

WD Black SN8100

A Gen5 SSD that's still not worth it

Credit: Source: Western Digital

Gen5 NVMe SSDs aren't anything new, but they still don't justify the price, at least for gaming builds. The WD Black SN8100 is one of the newer models that has impressed the community with its blazing-fast performance and attractive pricing. Going toe-to-toe with many pricier alternatives, the SN8100 boasts transfer speeds of almost 15,000MB/s, but that number doesn't really do much for gaming performance. Even outside in-game loading times, your PC won't feel any different from a system rocking a decent Gen4 SSD.

I've owned two WD SSDs by now, and can attest to the reliability and performance of the brand. However, a Gen5 SSD that still costs over $200 for a 2TB model is overkill for most gamers. When you can buy a 2TB Gen4 NVMe for around $120, and still get the same performance in almost every scenario, there's no case to be made for the WD Black SN8100. Professionals and enthusiasts can always justify the premium, but for most of us, Gen5 SSDs are still pointless.

Corsair Dominator Titanium DDR5

I wish someone would gift me this one

I love a good-looking RGB memory kit as much as the next guy, but the Corsair Dominator Titanium is the definition of overkill when it comes to DDR5 RAM. Featuring one of the most jaw-dropping designs on the market, this lineup features high-performance, premium kits that can instantly elevate the look of any build. I simply adore the white variant, but even the DDR5-6000 CL30 32GB kit costs almost $200, nearly double that of most other alternatives on the market.

No one said this was an affordable product, but it's a bit too pricey just for superior RGB lighting. Don't get me wrong, I'd love to have one of these in my next build, but I can't justify spending double on memory instead of using that $100 on a better motherboard or more storage. I've not seen a better-looking RAM yet, but looks can only convince me so much. If Corsair decides to drop the price by the time I'm ready to move to AM5, I'd be happy to reconsider.

RTX 5080

My dream upgrade that never happened

I once wanted to upgrade from my RTX 3080 to the RTX 5080, but the GPU market decided to throw a fit yet again, and I'm still rocking my Ampere GPU. The RTX 5080, though not a value GPU by any standard, launched at the same price as the RTX 4080 Super, offering a healthy boost in performance over its predecessor. It's a different story that it was never available for around $1,000 for months after launch, but for those with the money to splurge on a high-end 50 series GPU, this was the card to buy.

In late 2025, I can't recommend the average gamer stretch their budget to the degree that an RTX 5080 seems within reach. I can see 3–4 AIB models listed for under $1,000 on Amazon, but that's still a lot of money to throw on a graphics card, especially if you already have an RTX 40 series GPU. The generational improvements have been unimpressive this time, and the immense focus on AI-generated frames can only sway the market sentiment so much. You should rather spend your money on an RTX 5070 Ti or RX 9070 XT, if you're building a new PC right now.

Ryzen 7 9800X3D

The king of gaming CPUs is a complicated offering

AMD's latest 8-core Ryzen X3D CPU is undoubtedly the chip to beat when it comes to gaming CPUs. The Ryzen 7 9800X3D boasts unparalleled performance, but only when certain conditions are met. You also need to have either an RTX 5090 or RTX 5080 to fully realize its potential; otherwise, it feels like a regular 6-core or 8-core CPU. If you're gaming at 4K, the difference in FPS will be determined mostly by your GPU. And for $450, it's hard to make a case for the Ryzen 7 9800X3D, even after taking into account its class-leading performance.

So, even people building $2000 gaming PCs should not consider a Ryzen X3D CPU, since the extra budget is better spent on a more powerful graphics card. The Ryzen 7 9800X3D is a luxury CPU, pure and simple, and can't justify its price to most people, despite its stellar performance. Once you have the budget to secure an RTX 5080 or RTX 5090, you can consider spending $450 on the 9800X3D.

The best hardware is often not the best for your needs

The right components for your PC are the ones that strike the right balance between performance and price in your budget. For this reason, outstanding components like the Ryzen 7 9800X3D, RTX 5080, and Noctua NH-D15 will always be too expensive for most gamers. They're not bad products, but justifying the price premium is hard when you consider the alternatives.

Secondly, the beige-and-brown Noctua esthetic doesn't work for everyone. Lastly, the NH-D15 is just too big for many cases, dominating the visual footprint of your build, often negatively. Many compact cases won't be able to accommodate it in the first place. A cheap air cooler or $100 AIO liquid cooler are overall better choices than the phenomenal NH-D15.

WD Black SN8100

A Gen5 SSD that's still not worth it

Credit: Source: Western Digital

Gen5 NVMe SSDs aren't anything new, but they still don't justify the price, at least for gaming builds. The WD Black SN8100 is one of the newer models that has impressed the community with its blazing-fast performance and attractive pricing. Going toe-to-toe with many pricier alternatives, the SN8100 boasts transfer speeds of almost 15,000MB/s, but that number doesn't really do much for gaming performance. Even outside in-game loading times, your PC won't feel any different from a system rocking a decent Gen4 SSD.

I've owned two WD SSDs by now, and can attest to the reliability and performance of the brand. However, a Gen5 SSD that still costs over $200 for a 2TB model is overkill for most gamers. When you can buy a 2TB Gen4 NVMe for around $120, and still get the same performance in almost every scenario, there's no case to be made for the WD Black SN8100. Professionals and enthusiasts can always justify the premium, but for most of us, Gen5 SSDs are still pointless.

Corsair Dominator Titanium DDR5

I wish someone would gift me this one

I love a good-looking RGB memory kit as much as the next guy, but the Corsair Dominator Titanium is the definition of overkill when it comes to DDR5 RAM. Featuring one of the most jaw-dropping designs on the market, this lineup features high-performance, premium kits that can instantly elevate the look of any build. I simply adore the white variant, but even the DDR5-6000 CL30 32GB kit costs almost $200, nearly double that of most other alternatives on the market.

No one said this was an affordable product, but it's a bit too pricey just for superior RGB lighting. Don't get me wrong, I'd love to have one of these in my next build, but I can't justify spending double on memory instead of using that $100 on a better motherboard or more storage. I've not seen a better-looking RAM yet, but looks can only convince me so much. If Corsair decides to drop the price by the time I'm ready to move to AM5, I'd be happy to reconsider.

RTX 5080

My dream upgrade that never happened

I once wanted to upgrade from my RTX 3080 to the RTX 5080, but the GPU market decided to throw a fit yet again, and I'm still rocking my Ampere GPU. The RTX 5080, though not a value GPU by any standard, launched at the same price as the RTX 4080 Super, offering a healthy boost in performance over its predecessor. It's a different story that it was never available for around $1,000 for months after launch, but for those with the money to splurge on a high-end 50 series GPU, this was the card to buy.

In late 2025, I can't recommend the average gamer stretch their budget to the degree that an RTX 5080 seems within reach. I can see 3–4 AIB models listed for under $1,000 on Amazon, but that's still a lot of money to throw on a graphics card, especially if you already have an RTX 40 series GPU. The generational improvements have been unimpressive this time, and the immense focus on AI-generated frames can only sway the market sentiment so much. You should rather spend your money on an RTX 5070 Ti or RX 9070 XT, if you're building a new PC right now.

Ryzen 7 9800X3D

The king of gaming CPUs is a complicated offering

AMD's latest 8-core Ryzen X3D CPU is undoubtedly the chip to beat when it comes to gaming CPUs. The Ryzen 7 9800X3D boasts unparalleled performance, but only when certain conditions are met. You also need to have either an RTX 5090 or RTX 5080 to fully realize its potential; otherwise, it feels like a regular 6-core or 8-core CPU. If you're gaming at 4K, the difference in FPS will be determined mostly by your GPU. And for $450, it's hard to make a case for the Ryzen 7 9800X3D, even after taking into account its class-leading performance.

So, even people building $2000 gaming PCs should not consider a Ryzen X3D CPU, since the extra budget is better spent on a more powerful graphics card. The Ryzen 7 9800X3D is a luxury CPU, pure and simple, and can't justify its price to most people, despite its stellar performance. Once you have the budget to secure an RTX 5080 or RTX 5090, you can consider spending $450 on the 9800X3D.

The best hardware is often not the best for your needs

The right components for your PC are the ones that strike the right balance between performance and price in your budget. For this reason, outstanding components like the Ryzen 7 9800X3D, RTX 5080, and Noctua NH-D15 will always be too expensive for most gamers. They're not bad products, but justifying the price premium is hard when you consider the alternatives.

item.itunes:summary:
There's nothing quite like a good medieval fantasy game, is there? The clash of steel, the whisper of magic, and the thrill of forging your destiny in lands untouched by modernity. That's where the charm of medieval fantasy games lies, and it never fades, either.

These games pull you into their worlds while remaining faithful to medieval times and lore. Sure, there's an occasional dragon or witch, but when it comes to the atmosphere and the world they craft, these games make sure you get the medieval experience in every sword swing and spell cast. For the longest time, games set in medieval times weren't my cup of tea, and yet, some of these games changed that opinion for the better. As such, you owe it to yourself to at least try these greatest medieval fantasy experience once in your life.

Dragon Age Origins (2009)

An absolute masterclass in storytelling

Dragon Age: Origins stands as arguably the most perfectly-balanced RPGs of all time. It's dark, brutal, and deeply human, and it's filled with characters who feel real and choices that actually matter. Before BioWare lost its Midas touch, it was Dragon Age: Origins that stood tall in the studio's portfolio as their perfect title.

The game's world-building is spectacular, its writing is unforgettable (I could probably recite some dialogs I don't even know if I remember), and its combat, a decade-and-a-half later, is still satisfying in a classic, tactical way. This is a journey that you must absolutely go on, shaping the course of Ferelden as you make your choices.

If there's ever been a game that defines the modern medieval fantasy genre, it's truly The Witcher 3. There's nothing quite like a good medieval fantasy game, is there? The clash of steel, the whisper of magic, and the thrill of forging your destiny in lands untouched by modernity. That's where the charm of medieval fantasy games lies, and it never fades, either.

These games pull you into their worlds while remaining faithful to medieval times and lore. Sure, there's an occasional dragon or witch, but when it comes to the atmosphere and the world they craft, these games make sure you get the medieval experience in every sword swing and spell cast. For the longest time, games set in medieval times weren't my cup of tea, and yet, some of these games changed that opinion for the better. As such, you owe it to yourself to at least try these greatest medieval fantasy experience once in your life.

An absolute masterclass in storytelling

Dragon Age: Origins stands as arguably the most perfectly-balanced RPGs of all time. It's dark, brutal, and deeply human, and it's filled with characters who feel real and choices that actually matter. Before BioWare lost its Midas touch, it was Dragon Age: Origins that stood tall in the studio's portfolio as their perfect title.

The game's world-building is spectacular, its writing is unforgettable (I could probably recite some dialogs I don't even know if I remember), and its combat, a decade-and-a-half later, is still satisfying in a classic, tactical way. This is a journey that you must absolutely go on, shaping the course of Ferelden as you make your choices.

item.itunes:title: The single best software upgrade I made to my PC wasn’t a productivity suite, it was a tiny free utility
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
When you are trying to keep a modern PC zippy on a relatively small drive, like my 256GB SSD on an HP Spectre or 512GB SSD on an AMD build, that terrifying ‘Low Disk Space’ notification is a constant threat to your PC’s performance.

The worst part is that Windows’ own storage settings are nearly useless, offering a vague, slow summary that makes hunting down the gigabyte-sized culprits a tough task. I used to waste several minutes every week digging through folders, wondering where all my system space evaporated.

That frustration ended the day I found WizTree. It wasn’t a major software upgrade or a new productivity suite; it was a tiny, free utility that transformed my storage management in no time.

The frustration of Windows storage

Still scanning after several minutes

With dozens of apps, games, and large video files, managing storage on my 512GB SSD was a constant struggle. Watching my essential drives turn red was a frequent nightmare. It wasn’t just my major applications that suffered; the slowdown bled into everything.

I noticed frustrating lag spikes while typing a blog post in Microsoft Word, and even opening File Explorer felt ages, all because my system was running low on storage.

The situation became critical when I couldn’t even perform essential maintenance — every attempt to run a necessary Windows Update failed because the system demanded 10 or 15GB of temporary space, and it simply couldn’t allocate it.

Like many, I simply navigated to Settings -> System -> Storage, but that tool is basic at best. First of all, it takes quite a while to scan the drive, and even the Storage Sense didn’t help much.

I needed a tool that could give me instant, transparent insight into my drive (and even connected devices), bypassing the sluggish data provided by Microsoft’s own utilities.

WizTree: The speed revolution

Blazing fast

The moment I first ran WizTree, I understood what a true software upgrade felt like. I selected my heavily burdened SSD, hit the Scan button, and braced myself for a few minutes of waiting. Instead, my entire drive — hundreds of thousands of files were scanned and visually mapped in a few seconds only.

Windows and other disk analyzers manually scan the file system one folder at a time. On the other hand, WizTree accesses the drive’s Master File Table (MFT) — a pre-made index of every file on an NTFS drive.

Beyond the speed, I found WizTree to be quite accurate. Unlike some older tools that might misreport file sizes, WizTree gives me numbers that match what Windows itself reports for allocated space.

Best of all, it’s not limited to just my main drive; I can even plug in large external hard drives for backups or media and run the same near-instant scan and get complete control over my entire digital storage footprint. WizTree completely redefined what ‘fast’ disk management means.

The visual diagnosis

Treemap is quite handy

Speed alone is only half the story. The true genius of WizTree lies in its display. As soon as the scan completes, it displays the data not just in a list, but as a vibrant, color-coded Treemap.

Imagine your entire hard drive laid out before you as a giant block of color. The size of any rectangle on that map directly corresponds to the size of the file or folder it represents.

My eyes immediately went to a massive, red block tucked away in a folder — it was a 30GB file from an old video editor I had forgotten about. I spotted that single culprit in under one second. The Treemap turns storage management into a visual puzzle where the biggest pieces are impossible to miss.

Beyond cleanup

The quality-of-life and productivity benefits

WizTree brought countless quality-of-life benefits that boosted my productivity. I was no longer wasting 30 minutes every week or two in file cleanup. Now, if I need space for a new project or a game download, I can launch WizTree and have a complete, actionable list of targets in seconds.

The best part is how targeted and safe the cleanup feels. Unlike those vague system cleaner apps that promise to delete junk but leave you worrying about lost files, WizTree simply shows me my data.

The ‘Top 1000 Files’ list is fantastic for spotting those individual files, like screen recordings or a giant installer. Furthermore, the ability to quickly sort by file extension helped me identify and handle unnecessary data, such as old .zip files or duplicate photos.

Overall, this tiny, powerful utility ensures that my PC stays fast and ready for any task.

Diagnose and fix your slow PC

A full hard drive is the silent thief that murders PC performance. It’s not just an annoyance; it’s a productivity-killing mystery. WizTree proved that a simple, portable, and free utility can be a far superior investment than the most elaborate productivity suite. If you own an SSD and are tired of the constant storage mystery, this is the one tool you need to download right now.

Once WizTree is set up and running, check out these apps to boost your productivity on Windows.

Overall, this tiny, powerful utility ensures that my PC stays fast and ready for any task.

A full hard drive is the silent thief that murders PC performance. It’s not just an annoyance; it’s a productivity-killing mystery. item.itunes:title: I turned to NotebookLM to set up a self-hosted LLM — here's how it went
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
I’ve always been a tad bit embarrassed admitting this, especially as someone who writes about tech for a living and is also majoring in computer science, but I have absolutely no idea how self-hosting works. Sure, I know what it means, but I've never really properly self-hosted anything before. Even when I have, I’ve just blindly followed a YouTube tutorial step by step, copying commands without really understanding what any of them did.

Recently, I've been hearing more and more people talk about running Large Language Models (LLMs) locally on their devices and loving it, which is essentially "self-hosting" your own AI. Even without knowing too much about the self-hosting world, I still understand the benefits that come with it: much faster performance, complete privacy, and no need for an internet connection every time you want to use it.

At the same time, I’m too intimidated to even know where to start. Every guide I’ve come across throws around technical terms like containers, models, and APIs as if everyone already knows what they mean (and I clearly don’t). So, I decided to turn to the tool I use whenever I need to study something I’m unfamiliar with: NotebookLM — to help me figure out all this self-hosting-an-LLM stuff.

Why NotebookLM felt like the right tool for this

It’ll guide you step by step

Nowadays, when you don't really know how to do something (technical or not), the best course of action is typically to turn to an AI chatbot. Like most people, my first instinct when I wasn’t sure how to go about self-hosting was to ask ChatGPT and Perplexity, and both had pretty much the same approach. They threw a bunch of information at me, compiled from various sources across the web and their own training data.

For instance, ChatGPT started off with the different setup types (local-only or server-based), and then mentioned that the next step was to install a “local runner” like Ollama, which it described as the easiest. It gave me various methods to run an LLM and even included optional steps if I wanted a web interface like ChatGPT. ChatGPT’s response included terminal commands and recommendations for compatible models. It felt like it had merged different guides and approaches into one massive, dense answer.

While I’m sure the information was certainly useful, it was way too overwhelming. I instantly knew that using an AI chatbot alone wasn’t the best approach here. A YouTube video could help, but I wouldn’t really be able to ask follow-up questions or get clarifications on the parts I didn’t understand. I realized there was only one tool that could help me here: NotebookLM. With it, I could still benefit from AI guidance, yet have much more control over the pace and structure of my learning.

The biggest benefit was that I could hand-pick the sources I wanted NotebookLM to reference to help me learn how to set up a self-hosted LLM. I managed to find a couple of guides online and YouTube videos, and uploaded them as sources to a new NotebookLM notebook.

I also added a relevant XDA article, 7 Things I Wish I Knew When I Started Self-Hosting LLMs, since I thought it would give me practical tips from someone who had already been through the process.

Once you add sources to a NotebookLM notebook, any responses you get are directly grounded in the material you’ve provided. The responses also include clickable citations, and hovering over them shows exactly where NotebookLM pulled the information from your sources, which made it incredibly easy to cross-reference and verify everything.

Here's how I set up my first self-hosted LLM with NotebookLM's help

Never thought this day would come

Once I had uploaded my sources to a NotebookLM notebook, the next step was beginning the learning process. Whenever I want to learn something new with NotebookLM's help, I don't usually turn to any of its learning tools like Audio Overviews or Mind Maps.The very first thing I do to acquaint myself with the sources is use the Chat panel to ask questions I may have. Often, I simply ask it to summarize the entire source. In this case, I already knew I wouldn't have to use the other learning tools, as my aim here was simply to learn how to set the LLM up. So, I typed in a prompt where I explained my level of knowledge, outlining that I was a complete beginner with no prior experience in self-hosting. I asked NotebookLM to guide me step by step, using the sources I had uploaded, and to explain any technical terms in simple, easy-to-understand language. Here's the exact prompt I used:

I have absolutely no idea what self-hosting is or how to set up a self-hosted LLM. Can you walk me through how I can set up a local LLM on my Mac? Assume I’m a complete beginner and don’t know any technical jargon. I don’t want theory. I want to understand what tools or steps are actually involved, but explained simply.

A couple of days ago, NotebookLM launched a new Learning Guide Chat mode, as well as the option to create your own conversational style mode. Since my goal here was to learn how to do something, I chose the Learning Guide mode, as it's designed to guide you through complex topics in a structured, step-by-step way. It also takes your current knowledge level into account, adjusting explanations so that even beginners can follow along without getting lost.NotebookLM first began by explaining what self-hosting actually is, especially in the context of LLMs. It explained the benefits, and then, based on my complete beginner status, mentioned that my sources strongly suggested starting with LM Studio. It then briefly outlined the steps and asked me to confirm if I was ready to jump into them. NotebookLM guided me through each step with incredibly detailed instructions.

In each response, it focused on only one step and proceeded to the next only when I confirmed I was ready, which made the learning process feel manageable and well-paced. I performed the tasks right alongside it and asked any questions I had as I set up. NotebookLM helped sort out my queries instantly by referencing the sources I had uploaded.For instance, LM Studio automatically began installing a recommended model, and NotebookLM helped me figure out if it was a good fit for my needs and whether I should proceed with it or try a different option. Minutes later, my first local AI model was up and running. I then spent some time exploring its interface and testing basic prompts to make sure everything was working correctly (it was).

I had no doubts about how helpful NotebookLM would be

I've been using NotebookLM since it was a mere Google Labs experiment, and it's yet to let me down. I know it's the best tool to turn to when learning something new, especially when the topic seems too complex to tackle alone. I'm glad I finally decided to do this, and now I have a self-hosted LLM up and running.

item.title: HP ZBook X G1i review: Business as usual
item.itunes:title: HP ZBook X G1i review: Business as usual
item.itunes:author: XDA[RSS+]
item.itunes:summary:
The era of ultralight laptops is great for those who only need basic computing tasks, but for anything more strenuous, they fall flat. And that's where workstation laptops come in. These powerful machines are designed to be desktop replacements but portable, so that scientists, engineers, developers, and anyone with the need for speed can get their work done in the field, whenever needed.

And that's what we've got on the test bench today. The HP ZBook X G1i is a 16-inch mobile workstation with Pro-level Nvidia discrete graphics, plenty of storage and memory, and a powerful CPU to chew through data analysis or AI tasks. It's the kind of machine that's honestly not made for everyone, but if you know you need the power it contains, it should have no substitute. This model is (almost) the top spec, with everything maxed out except that the display is the 2K version and not the 4K, but with added extras like 5G connectivity, you might be too busy to notice the pixel count.

It's the kind of laptop that can crunch numbers for science, or train AI models without needing a data center's power. Or, it would be, if the discrete Nvidia GPU had more than 8GB of VRAM to use. AI models benefit when they can be entirely stored in VRAM along with the data from the token window, and this simply isn't enough memory for the types of workloads that the power user who would usually buy this laptop would need.

About this review: HP loaned me the ZBook X G1i for the purposes of this review. The company had no input in its content.

It's on the better end of panels that I've used this year without being OLED, and going with the hardier IPS is honestly the right play for a workstation anyway.

After testing with the Datacolor SpyderPro, I found this panel pretty good. It covers 100% sRGB, 98% AdobeRGB, 99% P3, and 96% NTSC, outperforming many of the consumer OLED panels I've used. It peaks at 458.7 nits of brightness, which is good, but only when the backlight is set to 100%.

It falls off sharply when you reduce the backlight to save power, and it's only 208.6 nits at 75% brightness, 109.5 nits at 50%, and 57 nits at 25% brightness. This makes it hard to use at anything but the highest brightness level, although 50% is close to the suggested target when doing color-accurate design work.

Adding to that is a disappointing 2.34 deltaE average color accuracy value. I don't like doing color work on anything above 2.0 deltaE away from expected color, and I'm sure many (most?) digital designers will agree. The luminance uniformity is even more scattered, and this is not the panel quality you'd expect from this laptop class in 2025.

We're used to Arrow Lake Mobile

But the Nvidia RTX Pro 2000 GPU makes things (a little) more interesting

I'm not sure exactly what performance figures I was expecting, but for a laptop that costs just shy of 6 grand, I was underwhelmed. It's true this is the Core Ultra 7 model and not the Core Ultra 9, but I expected more from the Nvidia RTX Pro 2000. Maybe the lack of GDDR7 VRAM (only 8GB) was the reason, but regardless of the Windows power profile, or if the laptop was plugged in, the results were very similar.

It feels like HP intentionally limits the power available in order to keep thermals in check, because at no point during my testing did the top of the keyboard get warm. Is that the behavior you'd want from a mobile workstation? I'm not so sure, and I'd prefer more power, slightly toastier fingertips while typing.

But benchmarks are only part of the story. Like last year's ZBook Studio 16 G11, the ZBook X G1i is a mixed bag in real-world usage. The occasional stutter when browsing or working on large documents is fine, really, and could be Windows being Windows. But it was so frisky when downloading updates or new programs, far more so than my significantly more powerful desktop PC. And trying to charge via the Thunderbolt 4 ports would always throw a "this charger isn't powerful enough" error, even when using a dock that matches the 150W power brick the workstation comes with.

In this realm, value takes a backseat to the simple equation of "can it do the task or not," and in that calculus, the HP ZBook X G1i is very good indeed.

Mobile workstations aren't known for their battery life, but this year, mobile chips are designed to be powerful and efficient. We ran the ZBook X G1i through the Procyon Productivity Test, and it tapped out after 4 hours and 23 minutes. That's the worst performer I've used all year, and I can't even blame it on the Blackwell discrete GPU. It's not quite as bad as gaming laptops, but it's time to rethink your priorities when your other choice as a creative professional is a MacBook Pro that can outlast by several times that number.

Should you buy the HP ZBook X G1i?

You SHOULD buy the HP ZBook X G1i if:

  • You need a mobile workstation, and cost is no object
  • You don't want a thick, noisy laptop
  • You need to run Windows-only programs

You SHOULD NOT buy the HP ZBook X G1i if:

  • You want to play games on your laptop as well
  • Your work isn't footing the bill
  • You need a long battery life

The HP ZBook X G1i is a seriously svelte and superbly powerful mobile workstation. On the higher-end models, like the one reviewed, it's got the chops to chew through complex calculations, 3D modeling, and anything else you could dream up. But if you can't afford to crank the sliders up to the top, it's no different from most consumer laptops, except the price tag is twice what you'd expect to pay for a comparable Arrow Lake mobile clamshell with no discrete GPU.
